title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009." It introduces enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Act titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers or suppliers if there is a significant risk of fraudulent activity based on various sources of information. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers or suppliers for screening, enhanced oversight, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. States may be required to implement these provisions as part of their state plans. Actions and determinations under this subsection are not subject to judicial review. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP. The Secretary may impose screening procedures on providers and suppliers, including licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, background checks, site visits, and disclosure of affiliations. An enhanced oversight period of 30 to 365 days may be established for providers as deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP. Providers and suppliers may be subject to enhanced oversight, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and claims review under titles XVIII, XIX, and XXI. The Secretary may extend oversight beyond 365 days if deemed necessary. Enhanced oversight for claims of durable medical equipment suppliers may be implemented if fraudulent activity is identified. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment supplied by a provider if there is excessive prescribing or authorization by a physician. A program will be established for periodic review of physician authorizations, with claims submitted quarterly for validation within a 90-day period. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrollment of providers and suppliers in cases of serious ongoing fraud within Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. This can be done for a specific category of providers or suppliers in a particular geographic area. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on provider enrollment in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs for fraud. A probationary period is established for new providers to undergo heightened review for legitimacy. The Secretary can suspend or terminate a provider's participation in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate. This action follows a review of claims and validation of physician prescriptions. Non-cooperation with validation processes can result in suspension or termination. The Secretary can impose a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000 on providers or suppliers who fail to cooperate in validating prescriptions. Amendments are made to prompt pay provisions for suspicious or potentially fraudulent claims. Amendments are made to Medicaid regulations to address suspicious or potentially fraudulent claim submissions, including enforcement of determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity. Amendments to the Medicaid regulations include procedures for enforcing determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity in provider categories. The State child health plan must outline procedures for enforcing these determinations and carrying out activities required by the Secretary. The amendments to the Medicaid regulations include provisions for program integrity in Medicare enrollments and renewals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Inspector General to identify providers and suppliers at risk of fraudulent activity. The amendments authorize additional funding for program integrity in Medicare, Medicaid, and the State children's health insurance program. The effective date for these amendments is upon enactment, with expedited implementation within 6 months. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will promulgate regulations to carry out these changes. Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment, which will be final immediately on an interim basis. The Secretary will allow for public comments on the interim regulation and may make changes based on feedback.
